topic.title: How to Set Fonts in Titles and Content

body.p: Suppose that in your customization CSS, you have defined your font (for example, Roboto) using a Google web font:

You can force a font on all elements, then style the ones that need to be different. The advantage of this method is that you do not need to trace all elements that have a font family defined in the built-in CSS files, you just reset them all.
In your customization CSS, add an !important rule that associates a font to all the elements from the document:
body.note: If you want to use the :root selector instead of the * sector, without the !important qualifier, the elements that have a predefined font specified in the built-in CSS will keep that font. If your content uses non-Latin glyphs, it is possible that the built-in fonts do not render them.
body.p: Next, identify the selectors for the elements that need to be styled with a different font than the one associated above. For information on how to do this, see: .
